div1.head: Military Orders for Robert P. Cooke, June 9, 1900
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders Vol 1 - 1900
Cooke

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 135. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, June 9, 1900.

1. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Sergeant
Ernest Hess, Troop L, 1st Cavalry, now at Camp Osborne,
Idaho, will be sent to the Army and Navy General Hospital,
Hot Springs, Arkansas, reporting upon his arrival to the com-
manding officer for treatment in the hospital. The command-
ing officer, Troop L, 1st Cavalry, will forward by mail to the
commanding officer of the hospital at Hot Springs the de-
scriptive list and account of pay and clothing of the soldier
prior to his departure from that post. Unless this soldier is a
proper subject for discharge for disability or change of climate,
the commanding officer of the hospital will on conclusion of
treatment send him to his proper station, as required by Cir-
cular, No. 16, of December 8, 1892, from this office.

2. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Burritt B. Haddow, Battery B, 5th Artillery, now in the hands
of the civil authorities serving sentence of imprisonment, will
be discharged without honor from the Army by the command-
ing officer, Fort Wadsworth, New York. This soldier is not
entitled to travel-pay.

3. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Michael Casey, Battery E, 7th Artillery, now in the hands of
the civil authorities serving sentence of imprisonment, will be
discharged without honor from the Army by the commanding
officer, Fort Preble, Maine. This soldier is not entitled to
travel-pay.

4. By direction of the President, under the provisions of the
act of Congress approved February 14, 1885, as amended by
act of Congress approved September 30, 1890, the Assistant
Secretary of War directs that the following-named enlisted
men, now at the stations designated after their respective
names, be upon their own application placed upon the retired
list created by that act, to take effect upon receipt of this order
at the posts, and repair to their homes:

First Sergeant John Donovan, Company E, 11th Infantry,
San Juan, Porto Rico;

Sergeant William Cuthbertson, Troop B, 1st Cavalry, Fort
D. A. Russell, Wyoming;

14. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Acting
Assistant Surgeon Robert P. Cooke, U. S. Army, will proceed
from Boyce, Virginia, to Tampa, Florida, and report by tele-
graph to the Adjutant General of the Army for further orders.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
✓

15. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Acting
Assistant Surgeon Robert P. Cooke, U. S. Army, upon the
completion of the duty assigned him at Tampa, Florida, will
proceed to Havana, Cuba, and report in person to the com-
manding general, Division of Cuba, for assignment to duty.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
✓

16. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the fol-
lowing assignments to regiments of officers recently promoted
are made:

Major Henry A. Greene (promoted from captain, 20th U. S.
Infantry), to the 14th U. S. Infantry, to date from May 31,
1900, vice Potter, promoted. He will proceed to join his regi-
ment. The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

17. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the retire-
ment from active service by the President, June 9, 1900, of
Lieutenant Colonel Carroll H. Potter, 22d U. S. Infantry, at
his own request, under the provisions of the act of Congress ap-
proved June 30, 1882, he having served more than forty years,
is announced. Lieutenant Colonel Potter will proceed to his
home. The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

18. The leave of absence granted 1st Lieutenant William H.
Wassell, 22d U. S. Infantry, in Special Orders, No. 62, March 3,
1900, Department of the Pacific and 8th Army Corps, and ex-
tended in paragraph 1, Special Orders, No. 94, April 21, 1900,
from this office, is further extended two months from June 5,
1900, on account of sickness.

19. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, leave of
absence for three days from June 11, 1900, is granted Captain
Zerah W. Torrey, 6th U. S. Infantry.
BY COMMAND OF LIEUTENANT GENERAL MILES:

H. C. CORBIN,
Adjutant General.
Comdg Genl Army
